Headline: Bill Clinton Unleashes Stinging Attack on Bernie Sanders
News: Supported byMILFORD, N.H. — Bill Clinton uncorked an extended attack on Senator Bernie Sanders on Sunday, harshly criticizing Mr. Sanders and his supporters for what he described as inaccurate and “sexist” attacks on Hillary Clinton.“When you’re making a revolution you can’t be too careful with the facts,” Mr. Clinton said, deriding Mr. Sanders’s oft-mentioned call for a political revolution.The former president, addressing a few hundred supporters at a junior high school here, portrayed his wife’s opponent for the Democratic nomination as hypocritical, “hermetically sealed” and dishonest.He even likened an incident last year, in which Sanders staffers obtained access to Clinton campaign voter data, to stealing a car with the keys in the ignition.Mr. Clinton discussed the race for nearly 50 minutes, and his comments took on a harder edge the longer he spoke. What began as a testimonial to Mrs. Clinton’s leadership and a statesmanlike lecture on her approach to issues evolved into an angrier recitation of grievances against Mr. Sanders and his fervent supporters.“ ‘Anybody that doesn’t agree with me is a tool of the establishment,’ ” Mr. Clinton said, mocking what he described as the central critique of Mrs. Clinton by Mr. Sanders.14 PhotosMr. Clinton’s comments represented an escalation in the language that he and Mrs. Clinton’s campaign have used to attack Mr. Sanders, who has maintained a sizable advantage in the polls here. Mr. Clinton made headlines in 2008 for fiercely defending his wife, and leveling tough attacks on Senator Barack Obama, but he has been largely restrained so far in this campaign.Criticizing Mr. Sanders’s hastily presented health-care plan, which Mr. Clinton claimed the Vermont senator had already disavowed, the former president asked: “Is it good for America? I don’t think so. Is it good for New Hampshire? I don’t think so.”He continued: “The New Hampshire I knew would not have voted for me if I had done that.”But Mr. Clinton’s most pointed remarks may have been when he took aim at Sanders supporters who, he said, use misogynistic language in attacking Mrs. Clinton. He told the story of a female “progressive” blogger who defended Mrs. Clinton online through a pseudonym because, he said, the vitriol from Mr. Sanders’s backers was so unrelenting.“She and other people who have gone online to defend Hillary, to explain why they supported her, have been subject to vicious trolling and attacks that are literally too profane often, not to mention sexist, to repeat.” Mr. Clinton, growing more demonstrative, added that the liberal journalist Joan Walsh had faced what he called “unbelievable personal attacks” for writing positively about Mrs. Clinton.In a demonstration of how engrossed he is in this campaign, Mr. Clinton recited the names of the regional newspapers that are backing his wife’s campaign and, in a rarity, mentioned Mr. Sanders by name.“Bernie took what they said was good about him and put it in his own endorsements,” said Mr. Clinton, fuming that Mr. Sanders used complimentary language from a Nashua Telegraph endorsement of Mrs. Clinton in his own campaign appeals.Then, reflecting the fury among Clinton campaign advisers over what they see as the kinds of behavior Mr. Sanders gets away with, Mr. Clinton noted that the senator’s campaign had used the image of an American Legion officer in New Hampshire without his permission.A week in February 1992 revived Bill Clinton’s presidential campaign and made the state hallowed ground for the Clintons.“If you point it out, it just shows how tied you are to the establishment,” he said.In a response, Tad Devine, a senior adviser to Mr. Sanders, called it “disappointing that President Clinton has decided to launch these attacks” and said Mr. Sanders would continue to focus on his message against the rigged economy, campaign finance corruption and income inequality. “Obviously the race has changed in New Hampshire and elsewhere in recent days,” Mr. Devine said.The appearance by Mr. Clinton, absent the entourage and crowds that usually surround the former president, was striking and somewhat poignant, and it felt far apart from the frenzied final campaigning happening around the state on Sunday. The junior high school’s small gym was not full, and only a handful of reporters showed up, at a time when campaign events are being flooded with dozens of national and international journalists.But with Mrs. Clinton in Flint, Mich., and other Clinton staffers absorbed in the primary, Mr. Clinton seemed almost on his own: He was introduced by a local mayor and Larry Lucchino, the former chief executive of the Boston Red Sox.Recalling his own, formative experience in this state, Mr. Clinton sounded wistful in reminiscing about his duels with Paul Tsongas, the Massachusetts senator who beat him here.“When I campaigned against Paul Tsongas we actually had substantive debates,” he said with perhaps a selective memory given the intense attacks at the time over allegations of Mr. Clinton’s sexual misconduct and his avoidance of the draft.Now, he complained, Mrs. Clinton is suffering through attacks from a would-be purist who, he said, is in reality a veteran politician hardly unfamiliar with the ways of politics. Citing Mr. Sanders’s attendance at a lobbyist-filled Democratic Party fund-raiser, Mr. Clinton expressed astonishment.“I practically fell out of my chair when I saw it,” he said.Turning to a vivid metaphor, Mr. Clinton suggested that Sanders staff members’ obtaining Clinton campaign voter data amounted to grand theft. Mr. Sanders apologized for the incident, but the former president dismissed that. He said that “in private they sent an email out” noting that the Democratic Party had left “the keys in the car, and all I did was drive off.”That line won laughs, which seemed to be what Mr. Clinton was going for. “I want you to laugh,” he told the crowd. But he did not seem to be in the mood for levity.Advertisement

Headline: Rival Factions of Top Donors Get Behind Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz
News: Supported byThe wealthy donors who have built a powerful shadow Republican Party of outside groups are rapidly cleaving into two mutually hostile and deep-pocketed factions, complicating efforts to deny the party’s nomination to Donald J. Trump, reports filed with the Federal Election Commission on Sunday showed.In the last six months of 2015, F.E.C. records show, a “super PAC” backing Mr. Rubio raised $14.3 million, including $2.5 million each from the hedge fund founders Paul Singer and Ken Griffin. The super PAC also drew significant support from donors who previously gave to groups backing Jeb Bush, among them Chris Cline, a coal executive, and Brian Ballard, a prominent Florida lobbyist.Mr. Cruz’s backers include the Wilks family of Texas, who made a fortune in the shale oil boom and are prominent donors to anti-abortion groups; Edward Czuker, a Los Angeles real estate developer and board member of the Republican Jewish Coalition; and the Illinois businessman Richard Uihlein, who gave $1 million to a pro-Cruz super PAC in January.See how the latest fund-raising numbers from the campaigns and outside groups stack up.“I think we’re rewriting history,” said Mica Mosbacher, a longtime Republican fund-raiser with ties to the Bush family, who decided to back Mr. Cruz because she was tired of the party nominating “moderates and career politicians.”“We’ve got a civil war within the party,” Ms. Mosbacher added. “And people want someone who is strong.”Mr. Trump has responded to their largess with an influx of his own money: In the last quarter of 2015, the billionaire businessman lent his campaign $10.8 million, according to F.E.C. reports, and raised just $2.7 million from other donors.Yet as caucusgoers gather in Iowa on Monday, Mr. Trump is at the top of the polls, and most of the money flowing into the Republican primary has been spent on attack ads targeting candidates other than the leader.Conservative Solutions PAC, which supports Mr. Rubio, has spent $3.2 million attacking Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey — an effort to stifle Mr. Christie in New Hampshire — and $3.3 million against Mr. Cruz. The main group supporting Mr. Bush, Right to Rise USA, has spent $1.5 million against Mr. Rubio and $366,000 against John Kasich. Super PACs backing Mr. Cruz have spent more than $1.4 million against Mr. Rubio.The expensive five-way shootout is a sharp departure from 2012, when virtually all of the Republican donors inclined to write seven-figure checks rallied behind a single candidate, Mitt Romney. And it presents a stark contrast to the Democratic contest, where the biggest checks raised by outside groups have all gone to Priorities USA, a super PAC backing Mrs. Clinton. Priorities reported that it had raised $51 million since the beginning of last year, including a $6 million contribution in December from the liberal hedge fund billionaire George Soros. The biggest outside group supporting Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont is funded entirely by a nurses union, pooling small contributions from members.The vast amounts of money still flowing into the race — combined with Mr. Trump’s knack for running an effective campaign without the benefit of substantial super PAC support — suggest that there may be no quick end to the nomination battle, despite Mr. Trump’s lead in most of the early Republican contests.While Mr. Bush raised less money for his campaign in the last quarter of 2015, the super PAC supporting him, Right to Rise, had $59 million on hand at year’s end, and likely has enough remaining to bludgeon other Republicans. Many of the group’s donors could move to support Mr. Rubio if Mr. Bush falters in New Hampshire.The pro-Rubio group, Conservative Solutions, had $14 million cash on hand, not including money held by an affiliated nonprofit that is not required to disclose its fund-raising. Mr. Cruz’s groups have recently spent another $1.4 million attacking Mr. Trump, who has overtaken Mr. Cruz in Iowa, a state where 60 percent of the Republican electorate identifies as evangelical. But the Cruz groups remain flush: As of the end of December, they had $32 million in cash on hand.David Barton, an evangelical activist in Texas who runs Keep the Promise, an umbrella group of pro-Cruz super PACs, said the group’s success was a reaction to earlier outside groups that wasted money on candidates uninspiring to conservative voters. Anti-establishment donors, he said, “finally have something that is closer to where they would like to give. And it is also closer to what they believe.”Yet the filings on Sunday reflect another reaction, as well. Mr. Sanders reported raising more than $33 million during the three months ending in December, most of it from grass-roots donors. In January, his campaign announced on Sunday, he took in an additional $20 million. The money has sustained him against Mrs. Clinton, who has built a more traditional campaign operation relying far more on donors giving the maximum contribution of $2,700. In Iowa, the two candidates are neck-and-neck, with Mr. Sanders holding on to a lead in New Hampshire. Both have enough money to compete effectively in the primaries and caucuses that follow.And Mr. Trump, beyond his loans to himself, has raised most of the rest of his money from small donors, including $2.7 million in the final quarter of 2015. Both Mr. Trump and Mr. Sanders have appealed to smaller donors in part by promising supporters they cannot be bought by the bigger ones. Both have eschewed the dominant super PAC model of the 2016 cycle, where candidates typically have dispatched a trusted aide to raise unlimited money for an outside group. Neither has set up committees of wealthy “bundlers” drumming up checks from friends and family members. Neither man spends much time at fund-raisers.“The traditional campaign spends most of its time raising money so that it can pay to get its message out,” said John Pudner, executive director of Take Back Our Republic, a conservative group that promotes small-donor giving. “Trump broke down the means, which is collect a lot of money. He’s found a different means to the same end.”Advertisement

Headline: Dropbox May Not Be LeBron James, but It Is Still in the Game
News: Supported byState of the ArtSo what’s really going on at Dropbox? Is it thriving or dying?Neither one, yet. When you look inside the company, you find something that defies Silicon Valley’s typical straight-up or straight-down narrative: a complicated story of incremental and potentially accelerating success, but one clouded by outsize dreams of yesteryear.According to Dropbox’s executives, nothing too terrible — it can just wait out the market freeze and perhaps grow into its $10 billion valuation. In other words, Dropbox can keep working and may yet turn into LeBron.“Sentiment about companies goes in cycles,” Drew Houston, Dropbox’s co-founder and chief executive, told me in an email. “Google, Apple, Facebook all went through multiple rounds of this. First, you can do no wrong, then you can do no right. Then people are like, ‘Actually this is a pretty good company,’ and around it goes. So you have to ignore the noise and stay focused on building great products and making customers happy. The rest will take care of itself.”Other numbers are also promising, they said. More than 400 million people use the company’s service — a place to keep documents online, so they can easily be shared and synchronized among different people and different computers — and the service is adding 10 million users a month. Dropbox also has 150,000 business customers, who pay annual fees of about $150 for each employee, and those ranks are growing by about 25,000 businesses a quarter.Insiders declined to specify Dropbox’s revenue and growth rate, other than to say there had been increases since its last funding round, when the company’s annual revenue was reported to be $400 million.Executives also said employee retention and hiring have not been hurt by the recent news. I asked several tech recruiters if they had noticed a diminished interest in working for Dropbox; none had. In the last year, Dropbox has hired from Facebook, Google, Microsoft and Twitter.“Dropbox is growing on the same trajectory as the best software-as-a-service companies ever — like LinkedIn or Salesforce,” said Bryan Schreier, a Dropbox board member and a partner at the investment firm Sequoia Capital, which has invested in the company. “I don’t know how we couldn’t be thrilled with that kind of performance.”But if Dropbox can still thrill its backers, it has also accumulated a chorus of skeptics. The company is one of several looking to ride two tidal waves now sweeping the business world — the trend toward business software that doesn’t stink, known as the “consumerization of information technology,” and the rising willingness of companies to store their most precious data on online servers, or in the cloud.Dropbox’s issue is that its products for business customers are relatively new compared with those of its rival Box, which was founded before Dropbox and began focusing on business users earlier. Dropbox is behind Box in attracting the most lucrative segment of the market — the largest companies who will pay the most to get their data online.Dropbox argues that the comparison with Box doesn’t take into account the differences in the two companies’ business models. Sure, Dropbox is developing its sales team and expanding its product offerings for businesses. But Dennis Woodside, Dropbox’s chief operating officer, said that its broad brand recognition makes the sales process more efficient — and thus cheaper — than Box’s. When Dropbox visits a company’s chief information officer on a sales call, it has something Box struggles to show — a large base of the company’s employees who are already using its service.“We fish in a pond that’s used to our product,” Mr. Woodside said. In the last quarter, Dropbox signed up 13 large companies with more than 1,000 users each, he said, three times as many as in the same period last year.Mr. Schreier of Sequoia Capital said Dropbox’s potential for profit was more attractive than Box’s, and argued that when Dropbox eventually goes public, investors will recognize that difference.Aaron Levie, Box’s chief executive, disputed this assertion. “Our differentiation and maturity in the enterprise market is what wins those customers,” he said. A large and costly sales team also makes a difference, Mr. Levie argued, which is why he seemed to scoff at the notion of Dropbox as a competitor. “We’re mostly competing with Microsoft in the enterprise, not Dropbox,” he said.Because one company is public and one is private, and because they operate so differently, it is difficult to say whether Box or Dropbox — not to mention Google or Microsoft — will ultimately run away with the enterprise cloud services business. Analysts say that at the moment, the market is big enough, and wide open enough, for all of these companies to thrive.The murkier issue is not whether Dropbox can build a good business, but whether it can ever become the $10 billion goose that investors had once seen it as. Reports of Dropbox’s demise are premature. But so are reports of its comeback.An earlier version of this column misstated the fees Dropbox charges its business customers. The fees are about $150 annually for each of the business’s employees, not for each business.Advertisement

Headline: Who Killed the Sheridans?
News: FeatureThe police say a prominent New Jersey lawyer killed himself and his wife of 47 years. Their sons refuse to believe it.Supported bySmoke billowed from a window on the second floor. Firefighters did not have to bust down the front door to get inside, because it was unlocked, as were several other entrances to the house. The dense smoke slowed them as they climbed the stairs to the second floor, but once inside the burning master bedroom, they extinguished the flames quickly. The fire had been confined to this one room, even though it was fed by an accelerant — gasoline, poured on the floor from a container that had been carried up from the garage. Two bodies lay on the floor, face up.The couple immediately threw their clothes and belongings back in their bags; when their car did not come quickly enough after Mark called for it, he went down to the garage to get it himself. They weren’t out of Manhattan yet when Matt, who was getting updates from a neighbor, called again and told Mark that his parents were dead.Mark began making his own calls as he drove. ‘‘I don’t know how fast I was going, but I was flying,’’ he says. ‘‘I think my first call was to Chris Porrino’’ — who was Gov. Chris Christie’s chief counsel — ‘‘and I say: ‘Chris, my mom and dad died, and nobody’s answering my questions. I understand the Somerset County prosecutor is at our house. I don’t know the Somerset County prosecutor, but can you have him call me?’ And Chris is a great guy, and he says, ‘Sure,’ and I’m literally pulling into my parents’ neighborhood when the prosecutor calls me.’’The prosecutor, Geoffrey Soriano, told him that the deaths were no accident. ‘‘He says to me: ‘It’s not just a fire. It looks like it was set intentionally, and it looks like your parents were stabbed.’ And I say, ‘All right,’ and I thank him.’’Mark went into ‘‘lawyer mode.’’ He was determined to keep his emotions at bay, to ask questions, sift through information and begin to make some sense of what had just happened to his parents. He had picked up one of his younger brothers, Tim, along the way. Another brother, Dan, was already in front of the house amid what was now a crush of people: neighbors, curious onlookers, the police and news media. Matt was the one brother still absent; he lived at home with his parents but had left the day before to go fishing on Fishers Island in Long Island Sound.A detective approached Mark Sheridan as he was getting out of his car and told him that family members were not allowed in the house. It was an active crime scene. ‘‘They’re asking us a lot of questions, but we’re not getting a lot of information,’’ Mark says. ‘‘They say, ‘Where’s Matt?’ And I tell them he’s on 287, just crossing from New York into New Jersey, and it will be about an hour before he’s here. And they say, ‘O.K., when he gets here, we would like to talk to you all.’ ’’Standing with other family members in a neighbor’s driveway, Mark did not have much to do but peer up at the bedroom where his parents died. Smoke was no longer visible, but he could still smell it.Later reports described the scene that emergency responders encountered in the master bedroom. John Sheridan, 72, had been found on the floor at the foot of the bed, with a partly burned armoire on top of him. Joyce, 69, was found to the left side of the bed. Matches, knives and a gas can lay nearby. Both husband and wife were dead at the scene. Joyce’s autopsy, performed by an assistant state medical examiner, Eddy Lilavois, showed that she suffered first- and second-degree burns and 12 stab wounds, mostly to her scalp, forehead and hands. The one that killed her was a wound to the chest that perforated her aorta. Her death was ruled a homicide. John, according to Lilavois’s autopsy, had five knife wounds to his neck and torso and a blunt-force injury that caused five broken ribs. The presumption was that the fractures came from the armoire falling on top of him. Unlike Joyce, he had soot in his mouth, nose and lungs, which indicated that he was alive when the fire started.John’s cause of death was listed as ‘‘pending further studies,’’ and the manner of death ‘‘pending investigation.’’ Yet the Somerset County prosecutor’s office was already giving strong hints that detectives were no longer searching for suspects — if, in fact, they ever had been. ‘‘We are quite confident that there exists no threat to either the immediate neighborhood or to the local community,’’ Soriano’s spokesman told reporters four days after the fire. The medical examiner had concluded that the cuts on John Sheridan were ‘‘hesitation wounds,’’ a term of art that Mark Sheridan first heard three days after his parents died, during a tense meeting at Soriano’s office in Somerville.‘‘I say: ‘What’s that? What are hesitation wounds?’ And one of the prosecutors says that’s what typically happens when someone tries to kill themselves and can’t accomplish it. And so that’s a powder keg. I’m thinking to myself: What are you saying? What are you talking about? Speak up if you’ve got something to say. Don’t lawyer me.’’The detectives laid out their theory: John Sheridan had killed his wife, set fire to their bedroom and then killed himself. ‘‘They told us, ‘If this is what we think it is, we’ll find the reason,’ ’’ Mark Sheridan says. ‘‘ ‘We’ll go through the emails and phones and other records, and there’s always something. Dad’s got a girlfriend, Mom’s got a boyfriend, there’s financial problems, a record of violence, there’s always something.’ ’’After the initial shock wore off, Mark and his brothers were furious. A horrific crime had occurred. Two people dead with stab wounds. A fire deliberately set. Where was the urgency? Was a manhunt underway? Why had the detectives settled so quickly on such a preposterous theory of the case? Nothing could seem more unbelievable to the family than the idea that John Sheridan killed his wife and himself. The Sheridan brothers felt themselves being thrust from the role of grieving sons to that of amateur detectives.The family hired its own pathologist, Michael Baden, a consultant on numerous high-profile cases, formerly the chief medical examiner in New York City and the host of the HBO program ‘‘Autopsy.’’ With Lilavois, the state’s medical examiner, in the lab with him, Baden re-examined the bodies. The two doctors looked at the shape and depth of the wounds and considered whether they could have been caused by the two knives recovered at the scene, of which at least one, a kitchen carving knife, was used on Joyce Sheridan. The other was a serrated knife for slicing bread, with a rounded end. It would not have been an ideal weapon, and it wasn’t clear if it caused any of Joyce’s wounds. Most significant, Baden and Lilavois agreed that a third knife caused John Sheridan’s wounds, but investigators had not recovered it. How, in a murder-suicide, could a weapon be missing?When the Sheridan brothers were allowed to enter the house midweek, after detectives were done taking evidence from the location, they came upon a piece of metal on the bedroom floor. It had melted, then resolidified. It could have been a piece of the armoire or some other metal item in the bedroom. Or it could have been a knife. The recovered knives, however, were kitchen knives, made of metal alloys that burn at only very high temperatures — the kind of intense heat that quickly engulfs an entire room, if not a house. Only part of the bedroom was burned.John Sheridan’s body was found near the melted metal. He still wore his cotton undershirt; it was charred but not burned. A month later, an insurance adjuster discovered a fire poker in the adjoining bathroom, even though there was no fireplace upstairs. Could that, rather than the tumbling armoire, have been the cause of John Sheridan’s broken ribs?The family was angry. Why hadn’t these items been recovered by detectives? Mark Sheridan described his reaction to the melted metal: ‘‘I pick it up and I fling it across the room. Danny comes in and throws it across the room the other way.’’ A week after the deaths, he wrote the prosecutor an email, which was not composed with his usual lawyerly detachment. In the midst of enumerating what he perceived as a string of investigative shortcomings, he wrote, ‘‘I am on the verge of losing my mind.’’Sheridan took naturally to the role of wise man and mentor. ‘‘To the day he died, if I had a problem, I’d go see John and talk about it,’’ his brother Peter says. ‘‘How do we deal with it? What should I do?’’ John advised him on how to get into law school; years later, he steered the political process that led to his brother’s appointment to the federal bench by President George W. Bush.In 2005, John Sheridan moved into management at Cooper Hospital in Camden. The position was a departure from previous jobs, but his dexterity in the overlapping spaces of government and commerce proved to be no less useful. Cooper had ambitious plans but needed regulatory approvals and public financing. In partnership with the hospital’s chairman, George Norcross III, who is often described as the Democratic boss of South Jersey, Sheridan helped build Cooper into a health care powerhouse. During Sheridan’s tenure, the hospital opened a medical school and teamed up with the MD Anderson Cancer Center to build a $100 million treatment center. ‘‘In my next lifetime,’’ Norcross says, extolling Sheridan’s uncommon serenity amid the hurly-burly of high-stakes business dealing, ‘‘I would want John Sheridan’s personality.’’Joyce Sheridan was feistier than her husband, whom she met when he was tending bar in West Orange to pay his law-school tuition at Rutgers. Once, when Governor Whitman called the house looking for John, Joyce held the phone out just a few inches from her face and said to her husband, ‘‘I thought I told you to tell her to stop calling at dinnertime.’’ Joyce had been a high-school social-studies teacher. She volunteered for the classes with the most-challenged students, those who struggled academically or had trouble in their backgrounds.On Sept. 25, 2014, a Thursday, three days before the fire, John Sheridan spent a rare workday afternoon at home. A neighbor, Marsha Stencel, walked by with her granddaughter and saw both Sheridans outside, decorating the home for Halloween. Joyce made the kind of fuss over Halloween that some people do for Christmas. She invited Stencel and her granddaughter inside and showed them displays set out on tables: lit-up houses, ghoulish figurines. A set of antique papier-mâché pumpkins sat atop the mantelpiece.The Sheridans were neighborly, but they weren’t an especially social couple. They spent almost all their free time together, either with their sons and grandchildren or buying antiques for their New Jersey home and for the Federal-period house near Cooperstown, N.Y., that they had painstakingly restored. Some years back, John delighted his wife with a gift that he fetched for the Cooperstown property on a drive up to New Hampshire: a double-seated outhouse from the 1800s. He had a hole dug and set it up in the backyard, because he didn’t consider it authentic unless it could be used.‘‘Joyce ran the place,’’ says Stencel, who was their neighbor and friend for almost four decades. ‘‘She was in charge. They had someone cut the grass, do repairs. I don’t know if John would have known the right end of a screwdriver to use. That wasn’t him. He worked, and he worked a lot. But he did what good husbands do. When Joyce needed him, he was there.’’Stencel had no sense that day that anything was amiss. ‘‘They were joking around with each other,’’ she says. ‘‘They were normal, just John and Joyce.’’The next day, a nephew of the Sheridans who had a lawn-care business came by to work on the yard and gently chastised Joyce when he saw her carrying grocery bags in from the car. Near the end of her teaching days, she took a serious fall at school that precipitated a cascade of orthopedic problems and over the last 15 years underwent more operations than her family could count — on her back, shoulders and neck. She rarely complained, but she took a mix of painkillers. John was back at work at Cooper Hospital. He met with Gary Lesneski, the hospital’s general counsel, about a pending negative report on Cooper’s cardiac unit, a matter that was said to be troubling him. But, Lesneski says, ‘‘It was business as usual when I left his office that Friday.’’John Sheridan bought a couple of new dress shirts earlier in the week. He picked up his dry cleaning. He had a meeting scheduled at Cooper on Sunday afternoon. On Saturday evening at 6:36, less than 12 hours before the fire, he sent an email from his iPhone in response to a question from Norcross about whether Cooper was eligible for some post-Hurricane Sandy disaster-preparation grants. His answer went on for a couple of hundred words. It still reads like a cogent and clearheaded piece of writing.The report did not speculate about the couple’s last hours. About whether, for instance, they had gone to sleep that night, and John at some point crept out of the bedroom to gather the knives and other materials, or if he instead hid the knives in advance. Or if, perhaps, there had been some kind of all-night row that culminated in blood and fire. In writing about the knife wounds on each of the Sheridans, Soriano emphasized the contrasts in their location and severity. Joyce had cuts on her hands, which were considered defensive in nature; John had no hand wounds. Referring to John, he wrote: ‘‘All five wounds have been characterized by the assistant medical examiner as superficial in nature, consistent with self-infliction. However, one wound to the neck caused a small perforation to the right jugular vein and would be fatal without medical treatment.’’ Two causes of death were given for John Sheridan: ‘‘sharp force’’ injury — the cut to the jugular — and smoke inhalation.The toxicology reports revealed no surprises. Joyce had a mix of prescription painkillers in her system — ‘‘Mom was on enough meds to kill a small farm animal,’’ Mark Sheridan says — and John tested positive for what were described as cardiac drugs. DNA evidence was not conclusive. The report said samples collected from the knives were ‘‘consistent with that of John Sheridan’’ or could not ‘‘exclude’’ him as a suspect. But the actual lab reports indicated the swabs did not yield a usable sample and revealed not much more than that they probably came from a white male.No motives were put forward. Detectives looked at the couple’s cellphones and computers and conducted what they said were more than 180 interviews with family members, neighbors, friends and co-workers. They did not uncover any of the usual explanations, the ones that they told the sons would probably turn up: girlfriend, boyfriend, terminal disease, mental illness, financial woes. The best they came up with was that John was unusually agitated at work, over the pending state report regarding fatality rates after cardiac operations at Cooper. ‘‘With regard to work-related issues, family members and colleagues characterized John Sheridan as ‘disproportionately concerned,’ ‘genuinely worried’ and ‘overly worried,’ ’’ Soriano wrote.The report did not name the people who provided this information, nor did it say what John Sheridan had said or done specifically to leave an impression that he was not himself. Soriano concluded his report with several bullet points, which amounted to a sort of connect-the-dots finding of murder-suicide. Several related to the absences of things: no evidence of forcible entry to the home; no indication anything was stolen (six folds of cash totaling $950 were found on a night stand); no one having noticed any suspects departing the house or neighborhood.By the time the report was issued, the Sheridans knew what would be in it. This did not lessen the sting. ‘‘It’s the goodness in people’s lives that you hang on to,’’ Peter Sheridan, the federal judge, told me. ‘‘The prosecutor’s conclusion destroyed their legacy and the good that John and Joyce had done in their lives.’’Not that it helped the Sheridan family. After Soriano’s report came out — and Mark Sheridan attacked it in local newspapers — Raymond Bateman seemed to support his son’s protégé by writing a column in The Home News Tribune, a Middlesex County daily, that made the assumption that John Sheridan was mentally ill. It went on to compare him with the German airline pilot who deliberately crashed a commercial airliner into the Alps, killing everyone onboard. ‘‘As I write with tears about my friend, John, and, yes, as I, in horror, think about the innocent lives lost in the airplane crash,’’ Bateman wrote, ‘‘I recognize that mental depression must just completely overwhelm a person’s normal judgment.’’Mark Sheridan didn’t see anything that had impinged on his father’s state of mind or warped his judgment. The way it looked to him, an unimaginable family tragedy was now being compounded by official incompetence and rank stupidity. His interactions with the detectives left him exasperated. He would lay out his lawyerly arguments and try to convince them that they had put their facts together illogically or had not even gathered all the pertinent facts, but they were unmoved. He considered himself to be dealing with ‘‘misfits.’’Joyce Sheridan’s brother, Peter Mitchko, had urged Mark to publicly take on the prosecutor sooner, go after him in the newspapers rather than continue to lobby him privately while waiting for the final report. ‘‘The boys were fighting for their dad’s reputation,’’ he says. ‘‘My issue is: Who killed my sister?’’Could it have been his brother-in-law?‘‘No, it’s not conceivable. Anyone who knew John and Joyce doesn’t think it’s conceivable. And the complicated way they said he committed suicide? You stab yourself? Burn a building? The only thing he didn’t do is eat poison. He doesn’t leave a note. Nothing makes sense.’’Last spring, less than three weeks after Soriano released his report, Mark Sheridan filed a lawsuit on behalf of himself and his brothers. It sought to have their father’s manner of death changed from suicide back to undetermined, which would have the effect of reopening the question of who killed their parents. A three-judge panel instructed the family to instead pursue the case with the state medical examiner’s office, and in December, the Sheridans sent Baden’s written report to the medical examiner and formally requested a change in the manner of death. The matter could yet end up back in court.The state’s answer to the initial lawsuit did not address the merits of the investigation; it just argued that the family had no standing to mount a challenge. ‘‘The court should dismiss this appeal for lack of jurisdiction because no legal basis exists to compel a medical examiner to change his opinion about manner of death,’’ states the response, which was filed by the attorney general’s office.Matt left for his fishing trip the day before the fire. He favored an extreme form of the sport in which participants wear wet suits, swim several hundred yards from shore and cast for striped bass from rock formations, sometimes at night when the bass are thought to be most interested in feeding. He said goodbye to his mother on the way out and gave her a kiss. The last thing he remembers her saying to him was, ‘‘Don’t do anything stupid.’’ When he got back to Meadow Run Drive, after the deaths, the police searched his car. According to court documents, they found a small amount of cocaine, a digital scale and plastic bags coated with white powder. In one twist the Sheridan case would take, he was arrested that day. He has not been charged, and no trial date has been set.On one of the occasions I met with Mark at his Newark office, Matt joined us, wearing a sport jacket and tie. ‘‘He’d get mad if I wasn’t dressed correctly,’’ he said, referring to his brother. The twins have a similar manner: direct but wisecracking, with an inclination toward dark humor. They still talk about their parents in the joking way that adult children often do. Matt said he was usually in close touch with both his parents during the day and often responded to what his mother would call ‘‘emergencies.’’ I asked what kind of emergencies, and both brothers laughed. ‘‘Everything was an emergency with Mom,’’ Matt said. ‘‘She’d call me up and say: ‘I’ve got an emergency. Can you get some Reese’s Peanut Butter Cups on the way home?’ ’’Matt said his father had indeed been troubled by the negative report about Cooper’s cardiac unit, but he did not consider those work issues to be even remotely plausible as an explanation. (Nor did anyone else I talked to who knew John Sheridan.) Had they considered the possibility that their mother initiated some kind of episode that ended in the two deaths, because by all accounts, she was the more hot-tempered of the two? ‘‘We did,’’ Matt said. ‘‘We’ve had to have some miserable conversations among ourselves about the different possibilities, but we’ve had them.’’ They concluded it wasn’t possible. Because of her injured shoulders, Joyce, at 5-foot-2, could not have raised the knife high enough to cause the wounds on her husband’s chest and neck. And they didn’t think she could have created much force even if she had.Soriano’s report does not speculate on whether the murder-suicide was planned or a result of some sudden rage. The presence of the gas can, which came from the garage and was used to fuel a generator that powers a basement sump pump, would suggest planning, as would the knives carried up from the kitchen. But nothing else — neither forensic evidence nor interviews — suggests that John Sheridan was planning anything other than continuing to work.‘‘So he went into a rage and got a gas can?’’ Mark said. ‘‘And then he did a few wounds and stopped being in a rage? Rage killings don’t work that way. It’s not one and done.’’Matt added: ‘‘He switched knives? Why did he do that?’’They went back and forth like this for a few minutes. I felt as if I were listening in on a conversation they had been having for months. Where was the other knife? If the fire was hot enough to melt a knife, why didn’t their father’s shirt burn? Why didn’t the whole bedroom or even the whole house go up in flames? Matt sighed and said, ‘‘We’re not detectives, but we’re not idiots.’’In their telling, the whole Sheridan universe holds together. Their parents were civic pillars. Collectors of antiques. Their marriage made it through the inevitable bumps and endured for nearly a half-century. The prosecutor turned up not even a shred of a motive for John Sheridan. All four brothers were where they said they were — their cellphones had been examined; they were nowhere near Meadow Run Drive — and none were under suspicion.What about Matt, with his supposed possession of cocaine, and the scale and plastic bags? In the absence of alternative theories as to who killed the Sheridans, his arrest and whatever involvement he did or did not have with drugs has been a source of speculation and rumor. On the advice of his criminal lawyer, Matt would not talk about the drug arrest or anything related to it, so it was up to his brother to address it. I asked Mark Sheridan if he was upset when his brother was arrested on drug charges a few hours after his parents’ deaths. ‘‘Yeah, I was pissed,’’ he said. His tone of voice indicated he might still be.Had they considered that their parents were murdered by someone looking for Matt? ‘‘Yeah, absolutely we’ve talked about it,’’ Mark said. ‘‘We don’t believe it. First of all, Matt’s car wasn’t there. Matt wasn’t there on weekends, or hardly ever. So I don’t believe it, and nobody’s going to convince me otherwise.’’The family, however, strongly believes that the police never seriously considered any other suspects — that they zeroed in on John Sheridan and then spent months trying to prove their initial hunch. In light of that, how could the family eliminate any theory? ‘‘I can’t,’’ Mark Sheridan said. ‘‘Anything’s possible.’’Sheridan had just arrived at his office after an hour-plus commute from his home in Tewksbury. We sat in a conference room across from a big window overlooking Newark’s Penn Station. He has his father’s facial features but not his conciliatory, bring-everyone-onboard personality. ‘‘My dad was the cool hand,’’ he said. ‘‘I’m the drop-the-gloves guy.’’ Sheridan is a litigator who defends insurance companies against large claims. He has been referred to as an ‘‘attack dog’’ in his role as lawyer for the state Republicans. He does not object to the portrait. He characterized the numerous lawsuits he filed against New Jersey governors when his party was out of power as ‘‘torturing one Democratic administration after another.’’ His side gig was rich in entertainment value, a front-row seat to the theater of New Jersey politics. ‘‘You’ve got two choices,’’ he said. ‘‘You either take it all seriously, or you laugh at it.’’He put a paper coffee cup down in front of him when we started talking but never touched it. We happened to be meeting on the same day that David Wildstein, a former Port Authority executive and Christie ally, was in court to plead guilty on charges connected to the politically motivated lane closures on the George Washington Bridge. Two others were criminally charged at the same time. After his parents’ deaths, Sheridan stepped down from his role as counsel to the state Republicans, but he continued to represent the party’s interests in the scandal and is defending Christie’s 2013 gubernatorial campaign committee in a civil suit brought by people who were stuck in traffic on the bridge. He checked his cellphone just twice. He returned one call, to his wife, over the course of four hours. He is consumed with restoring his family’s reputation. ‘‘I’ll be damned if I’m going to allow them to tarnish my father and my mother and their legacy based on this half-assed investigation,’’ he said.The state’s theory makes no sense to Mark. His father lived an orderly life, and yet his supposed crime was inefficient and sloppy. He set a fire, a common tactic only when a perpetrator intends to flee and not be tied to a crime. ‘‘I’ve said to the prosecutor, ‘It’s bad enough you’re calling my father a murderer, but you’re also calling him a moron, as though he weren’t smart enough to work this out,’ ’’ Mark said. ‘‘ ‘You’re telling me this was planned, but he’s better than that.’ This would be the worst plan he ever came up with.’’Various experts have looked at the evidence in the case and found it unconvincing. Lawrence Kobilinksy, chairman of the department of sciences at John Jay College of Criminal Justice, noted, in particular, the missing weapon — ‘‘that’s huge,’’ he said — as well as the lack of a motive, the unpersuasive DNA findings and an arson that ‘‘makes no sense’’ in the context of a murder-suicide. The case, he told me, should be reopened.Mark acknowledges that at times he may sound detached from the horror of what happened to his parents. It is a coping mechanism, a way to avoid being emotionally wrecked. He spent his entire childhood inside the house where his parents died. He told me, almost offhandedly, that he and his brothers had been planning to have the structure ‘‘ ’dozed’’ — bulldozed — so they could sell the vacant lot. But they have delayed doing so. There are still bloodstains everywhere: a bloody fingerprint outside the door of the master bedroom, stains on the walls downstairs. Was it all really tested by investigators? Might it reveal the identity of the killer? These are the kinds of questions he contemplates. Knock down the house and have the rubble trucked to a landfill, or preserve it for the forensic value of the blood on its walls?The family is now waiting to see if the medical examiner’s office will change John Sheridan’s cause of death. ‘‘This is my shot at the prosecutor,’’ Mark said at one point in our conversation, referring to one of his recent court filings. ‘‘My shot at the medical examiner is going to come next.’’ I asked him about Christie, who oversees the state’s medical-examiner system and who appointed the acting state attorney general, John Jay Hoffman, whose office was opposing the appeal of the manner-of-death finding. Isn’t there some way for Christie to help him? ‘‘I am trying my best not to take shots at the governor,’’ he said.Sheridan understands why people are intrigued by the mystery of what happened to his parents: ‘‘I’ve said to my brothers, if we weren’t living this nightmare, it would be an interesting thing we’d be following.’’ He knows some will find it odd that his privileged and politically connected family feels badly served by law enforcement. ‘‘I get it,’’ he said. ‘‘I totally get it. I know it sounds offensive, but how do you deal with it if you’re not this family? If you don’t have the education, the knowledge, the connections, the financial wherewithal to fight the fight? I’ve got access. I’m sitting at the police station on the day my parents died, and the governor is calling to offer condolences. Not many people get those calls, right? And at the same time, you’re just getting screwed over, and there’s nothing you can do about it.’’Sometimes, at night, he dwells on an alternative explanation for his parents’ deaths. The backyards in the Sheridans’ neighborhood in Skillman are heavily wooded, and few of them are fenced. Anybody could have crept through the night, walked into the house and killed John and Joyce Sheridan. An almost prosaic explanation. Some crazed stranger did it, a person so unhinged he didn’t even bother taking the wads of cash in full view. Awful, but comprehensible.Michael Sokolove is a contributing writer for the magazine and the author of ‘‘Drama High,’’ about a drama teacher who transformed a school.Advertisement

Headline: A Make-or-Break Moment for Marco Rubio’s Candidacy
News: Supported byIf all goes as planned, South Carolina will be his mulligan.“Here’s what we know: Marco Rubio will certainly do better than Jeb,” Mr. Scott, one of the state’s two Republican senators, said on Tuesday after a Rubio rally that drew close to 1,000 in North Myrtle Beach. “He might even catch second place. And if we catch on fire, we have a long-distance shot at first.”The importance of doing well here is more than just a matter of changing the narrative for a campaign that needs something that looks like a win, even if that is only third place, behind Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas. Increasingly, with expectations for success growing, Mr. Rubio’s ticket out of South Carolina is looking like second place.Mr. Rubio sees a second chance to sew up the support he expected to break his way when he was riding high into New Hampshire. But that all came crashing down.After the debate, “those calls stopped,” said one supporter with deep ties to the campaign. “Totally frozen,” said another.Mr. Rubio’s campaign manager, Terry Sullivan, explained in a conference call with donors last week that he and his staff had badly miscalculated by advising their candidate there was little to be gained from a confrontation with Mr. Christie. And the fallout was more damaging than they could have anticipated: the worst news coverage, Mr. Sullivan joked, since O. J. Simpson made his getaway in a white Ford Bronco.The voters he needs to persuade are almost exactly the same groups he targeted in Iowa: higher-income, well-educated, younger and living in suburban and exurban areas. And his campaign has surveyed and targeted them extensively.A look at the latest results for Iowa and New Hampshire, and how this year compares to previous election seasons.“If you’ve got a Suburban and a sticker on it saying what cheer camp your kid went to,” Mr. Sullivan said, “you are a Marco Rubio voter.”As in Iowa, many potential Rubio voters are evangelical or born-again Christians who are drawn to Mr. Rubio’s religiousness, but who might be leaning toward Mr. Trump or Mr. Cruz.Even the background noise is the same: Mr. Trump and Mr. Cruz are tearing each other apart again. And as they trade accusations over who is the more trustworthy and authentic conservative — a fight Mr. Rubio’s advisers believe is seriously damaging to both, especially among undecided women — Mr. Rubio believes he can emerge largely unscathed.“When you see what happens in South Carolina,” Mr. Scott said, “it will carry momentum into Nevada, and then into Super Tuesday.”His renewed confidence seems to be loosening Mr. Rubio up as he speaks to his crowds here, unlike in his final days in New Hampshire when he looked rattled and sounded exhausted. He wears a big smile. People who come to see him are grabbing yard signs and literature.According to the Associated Press, Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton have each won enough delegates to claim their party’s nomination for president.He has started to improvise his remarks more frequently.As he spoke in North Myrtle Beach on Tuesday, Mr. Rubio tried a new, slightly more humorous explanation of what it means to live paycheck to paycheck: “It’s when you write a check on Wednesday but you know you’re not going to get paid until Friday, so you date it Saturday,” he said, insisting with a knowing smile that he had never done anything of the sort when he was younger.Turning a joke about his caffeine dependency into a dig at Mr. Trump, Mr. Rubio recited the old Red Bull slogan, “Gives You Wings,” saying, “When I’m president, everyone will have wings. Everyone. And Mexico is going to pay for them!”And as he introduced his older brother to the crowd, he laughed off their two-decade age difference. “Same dad,” Mr. Rubio cracked, then told a story of how when his mother was in labor with him, and his brother accompanied her to the hospital, the staff asked him to sign the birth certificate, thinking he was the father.The campaign’s biggest priority is undecided voters, who polls suggest make up perhaps a third of the Republican electorate. A plurality of voters who made their minds up at the last minute in Iowa broke for Mr. Rubio, accounting for his unexpectedly strong finish there.After he spoke to a crowd of several hundred outside Charleston on Tuesday, Mr. Rubio seemed to be making some progress.“Well, it was going to be Trump. But now I’m leaning towards Marco,” said Daniel Lewis, 24, a hospice administrator from Charleston, who almost perfectly matched the profile of the voters Mr. Rubio is trying to reach here: young, professional and from a densely populated area.Mr. Lewis said he was drawn to Mr. Rubio’s uplifting message and to his desire to make the American dream more attainable.Illustrating how fluid the campaign remains, however — and how easily high expectations can be dashed — Mr. Lewis said he was not totally sold just yet: “Rubio, I still don’t know if he has what it takes.”Advertisement

Headline: Japan Bond Yield Slides Below Zero and Stocks Fall
News: Supported byTOKYO — Given Japan’s outsize public debt, holding an i.o.u. from its government might seem like a risky proposition that would require the promise of a substantial reward.But this week, as global economic fears drove money into safer assets, investors in Japanese debt began essentially performing that service for free.On Tuesday, the yield on Japanese 10-year bonds, the benchmark of government borrowing, dropped to zero for the first time. They quickly fell into negative territory, meaning some investors were buying bonds despite knowing that if they held them until maturity, they would come away with less money than they paid.And on top of that, a strong yen dragged Japanese stocks down more than 5 percent in the worst trading day this year. The market opened lower again on Wednesday.The move was intended to bolster the Japanese economy, but the flight by global investors to perceived safe assets is complicating the effort.Like savers depositing money at a local bank, banks keep their own unused cash at the central bank. The interest they earn on those reserves — or do not earn, as the case may be — helps determine the cost of other kinds of borrowing and lending.The Bank of Japan’s new policy is intended to stimulate the economy, which narrowly avoided falling into recession last quarter. By making it unprofitable for banks to hold cash, Mr. Kuroda hopes to encourage them to lend more freely and get businesses and households to spend. He also wants to give a lift to consumer prices, which have been sagging after a welcome but short-lived bout of inflation.In other countries that have introduced negative interest rates, like Sweden and Switzerland, government bond yields have also been pushed below zero.Masamichi Adachi, a former central bank official who is now an analyst at JPMorgan Chase, said that the reversal in bond yields was bound to happen eventually, given the negative interest rate policy, but it occurred more quickly than many expected. The imposition of negative rates on bank reserves will not even take effect until next week.The speed, he said, was because of a factor that is complicating Mr. Kuroda’s stimulus program: a rush by global investors to buy the yen, which is seen as a safe currency at a time of economic uncertainty. The resulting rise in the yen’s exchange rate has hurt the Japanese stock market and darkened the outlook for inflation, canceling out much of the efforts of the Bank of Japan, or B.O.J.“The China slowdown, falling oil prices, fears about a U.S. recession — the headwinds facing the B.O.J. are very strong,” Mr. Adachi said.One goal of negative interest rates is to redirect investors’ money from bonds into more theoretically productive assets like property and stocks. But in at least one sector, finance, the policy has deepened the equities rout. Banks are reluctant to pass the costs of negative rates on to depositors, for fear they will pull their money out of their accounts en masse. Instead, the banks are absorbing the penalties themselves, cutting into profits.This week the yen has strengthened to a little over 114 to the dollar, about 10 percent stronger than its most recent low. That is bad news for the many Japanese companies that earn revenues outside Japan: the stronger the yen, the less their foreign-currency earnings contribute to profits.The Nikkei 225-stock average dropped 5.4 percent Tuesday, its biggest one-day drop since May 2013, as investors reacted to the potential blow to corporate earnings. It was down a further 0.7 percent in early trading Wednesday morning.Easy money from the central bank had kept the yen relatively weak since 2013, but a reversal appears to be gathering pace despite the central bank’s latest move.Japan’s status as a haven for investors can seem puzzling. It is carrying the heaviest government debt load in the world, at the equivalent of about two and a half years’ economic output. But most experts are sanguine about the risks. The debt is still amply funded by local savings. And taking the private sector into account, Japan as a whole is a major net creditor, not a borrower. That greatly reduces the risk of instability.For now, the bigger danger appears to be that efforts to get its economy growing again will stall. Stimulus by the Bank of Japan has played an outsize role in Prime Minister Shinzo Abe’s economic policy, known as Abenomics. One concern for government and central bank officials is that companies will resist demands to increase workers’ pay as the stronger yen eats into profits. That would block what the bank and many economists see as a crucial means of promoting spending and inflation.“Corporate management now has many excuses for not raising wages,” Mr. Adachi said. He added that the Bank of Japan would likely impose even steeper negative rates, something Mr. Kuroda hinted was possible in a policy speech last week.“One purpose of the B.O.J.’s move was to dispel the idea that it lacks ammunition,” he said. “Kuroda will continue to try and surprise the market.”Advertisement

Headline: Robin Chandler Duke, Philanthropist Who Championed Women’s Rights, Dies at 92
News: Supported byRobin Chandler Duke, a rags-to-riches grande dame who married an ambassador and became one of America’s best known advocates for women by championing reproductive rights and international family planning, died in Charleston, S.C., on Saturday. She was 92.Her daughter, Letitia Lynn, confirmed the death, at Bishop Gadsden, a retirement community. Ms. Duke for many years had homes in New York and the Hamptons, on Long Island.Ms. Duke’s life was full of storybook improbabilities: a lawyer’s daughter left destitute, a teenage model who lied about her age, a reporter, the wife of a fading actor, a single mother of two who succeeded as a television newscaster, a stockbroker and a public relations executive when women in those roles were rare.At age 39, she became the fourth wife of Angier Biddle Duke, the scion of two American dynasties. He was President John F. Kennedy’s chief of protocol, had already served as ambassador to El Salvador and would later become President Lyndon B. Johnson’s chief of protocol and the ambassador to Denmark, Spain and Morocco.With the wealth, prestige and connections of her second husband, Ms. Duke led the glamorous life of an ambassador’s wife for two decades, accompanying him to White House dinners and on assignments in Copenhagen, Madrid, and Rabat, Morocco, entertaining world leaders and royalty abroad and the crème of society at the Duke homes in Manhattan and Southampton, N.Y.But starting in the 1970s when she was in her 50s, Ms. Duke also independently embraced social and political causes, and for much of the remainder of her life she promoted and led organizations supporting abortion rights and legal equality for women, the stabilization of rising global populations and health and education programs in Africa, Asia and other parts of the world.She was the national co-chairwoman of the Population Crisis Committee/Draper Fund, which financed International Planned Parenthood; the president and, later, the chairwoman of the National Abortion Rights Action League; the president of its successor, Naral Pro-Choice America; a founder of the United Nations Fund for Population Activities; and the chairwoman of Population Action International.In 1980, President Jimmy Carter asked her to lead America’s delegation to the 21st United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization conference in Belgrade, Serbia, a five-week gathering of 2,000 delegates from 154 countries focusing on the clashing public policies of developed nations, third-world countries, the Soviet bloc and Western democracies. She was accorded ambassadorial rank.“She wasn’t Mrs. Angier Biddle Duke,” her husband said. “She was the Honorable Robin Chandler Duke.”Ms. Duke was a co-founder of the United States-Japan Foundation and was a director of the David and Lucile Packard Foundation, the World Childhood Foundation and the Charles A. and Anne Morrow Lindbergh Foundation. She was also a trustee of the Institute of International Education and an overseer of the International Rescue Committee.In 2000, she became a full-fledged ambassador herself. President Bill Clinton named her his envoy to Norway, and she served in Oslo in the final year of his administration.She was born Grace Esther Tippett in Baltimore on Oct. 13, 1923, one of two daughters of Richard Edgar and Esther Chandler Tippett. Her parents called her Robin, and she used the nickname all her life. Her father left his law firm when she was 15, and the family fortunes went into a tailspin. Robin had to drop out of a private school for girls. Her parents split up.Her mother moved with the children to New York, rented a room and found work as a tearoom cashier. Robin’s older sister, Peggy, became a photographer’s model, and at 16, Robin lied about her age and got a job modeling dresses for the clientele at Lord & Taylor. She was found out and fired, but managed to get other modeling jobs, including one at the New York World’s Fair in 1939, to help sustain the family.She also made contacts with editors at The New York Journal-American and in 1944 got a job as a writer for the women’s page. She used the byline Robin Chandler and covered society news, fashion and the occasional murder.As Mr. Lynn’s film career dwindled, it largely fell to Robin to support the family. With her background in journalism, she got a job at WCAU-TV, the CBS affiliate in Philadelphia, reading the evening news. The Lynn marriage came apart in the early 1950s, although the couple did not divorce until 1958.Robin’s struggle as a single mother echoed her mother’s experience. In 1952, she joined NBC’s new “Today” show, with Dave Garroway, as an anchor-reporter. She covered the national political conventions and Jacqueline Bouvier’s 1953 marriage to Senator John F. Kennedy. From 1953 to 1958, she was a broker at Orvis Brothers, and then, for four years, she was vice president for public relations at Pepsi-Cola.In 1962, she married Mr. Duke. His father, Angier Buchanan Duke, was heir to part of the American Tobacco Company fortune, most of which went to his cousin, Doris Duke. Mr. Duke’s mother was Cordelia Drexel Biddle, a Philadelphia socialite and writer. Mr. Duke had been President Harry S. Truman’s ambassador to El Salvador, and in 1963 he handled protocol for world leaders at President Kennedy’s funeral.Ms. Duke’s husband retired from diplomatic service in 1981. He died in Southampton in 1995 after being hit by a car while rollerblading.Besides her work for women’s rights, family planning and health and education programs, Ms. Duke was on the boards of the Guggenheim Museum, American Home Products, Rockwell International, the Emigrant Savings Bank, International Flavors and Fragrances and other organizations.She raised money and campaigned for presidential, congressional, state and local candidates, mostly Democrats, and was on a first-name basis with leaders in government, business and the arts.She received many awards and was often in the news, even in her 80s, attending fund-raisers for her causes.Besides her daughter Letitia, Ms. Duke is survived by two other children, Jeffrey Lynn and Biddle Duke; two stepchildren, Marilu Duke Cluett and Dario Duke; and four grandchildren.In an interview with New York magazine in 2005, Ms. Duke said her favorite job was working for The Journal-American when Fiorello H. La Guardia was mayor.She said: “What a delight he was! Bloomberg has some of the same personality, you know. But I really loved La Guardia. I was one of the lone women wandering around, and I guess if you’re a young, pretty blond girl, that helps, but he was so nice to me.”An obituary on Monday about the socialite and women’s rights advocate Robin Chandler Duke referred incorrectly to WCAU, the Philadelphia television station where she once worked. Although it is now an NBC station, it was a CBS affiliate at the time.Advertisement

Headline: How to Make Capitalism More Appealing
News: Supported byPolitical EconomyCapitalism is under attack. Witness the popularity of Bernie Sanders, the socialist running neck and neck in the opinion polls with Hillary Clinton for the Democratic caucuses in Iowa on Monday. To rehabilitate the system of free enterprise, it needs to be buttressed by a modern conception of fairness.Viewed from Mars, capitalism has been a huge success. Free enterprise has generated wealth and removed hundreds of millions of people from poverty. But viewed from Earth, what often stands out is how many have been left behind by the march of globalization and technology, while others have gotten ahead by methods more foul than fair.The classic left-wing response to the perceived unfairness of capitalism has been to tax and spend. That doesn’t work well. High taxes can sap entrepreneurial spirit, while high welfare spending can leave poorer people dependent on handouts.Just because that response has been tried and failed doesn’t mean it won’t be tried again. The success of left-wing populists like the Syriza party in Greece and the election of Jeremy Corbyn as leader of the Labour Party in Britain shows that such ideas still have appeal.This makes it important for centrists — whether they consider themselves left-wing progressives, radical centrists or liberal conservatives — to articulate a credible middle road. It should be based less on the view that fairness is the same as equality and more on the idea that people should get a fair crack at a good standard of life.There are two main aspects. First, it is important to tackle the foul methods by which people and companies get ahead and that make it tougher for hard-working, honest people to make progress.One example of this is evading or avoiding tax. This is rife in some countries, like Greece. But it is a global problem that makes people furious everywhere. Witness the anger in January in Britain over how Google, the Internet giant, was seemingly able to run rings around the authorities and pay what looks like a tiny amount of tax.Corruption, which is again widespread across the world, also creates indignation. Sweetheart deals between politicians and business line the pockets of the few to the detriment of the many.Another justified target of ire is the existence of markets that favor insiders at the expense of the general public. Finance is at the top of the list. The global financial crisis exposed how many bankers had a one-way bet: During the good times, they raked it in; during the bad, the state picked up the pieces. This was a mockery of how capitalism is supposed to work.Monopolies and vested interests are yet another source of resentment. Sometimes, the culprits are the oligarchs who pull the strings in government to get the rules written in their favor by giving bribes to politicians or senior officials.But often the beneficiaries of vested interests are not particularly rich or powerful as individuals. Greece is one of the best examples of this phenomenon. Over decades, it perfected the art of doling out special privileges to such an array of groups — farmers, notaries, pharmacists, civil servants, teachers and ordinary retirees as well as shipping magnates — that its economy gummed up.Such practices sap entrepreneurial spirit, but they do so by locking people out of opportunity rather than by using the methods of old-fashioned socialism. They also inflict bigger taxes on honest citizens and higher prices on consumers.A modern conception of fairness would put an assault of foul methods at its heart. But it would do more than that.Although successful societies need welfare states, most of Europe’s welfare states need refocusing. Part of the problem is that too much government spending is directed to what Europeans call the middle class rather than the needy.The situation varies from country to country, but the main goodies are generous state pensions for middle-to-high earners and tax breaks that benefit relatively well-off people. To be fair, some countries are reining these in. For example, Britain no longer offers such attractive incentives for rich people to save for their retirement. But in many countries, there is a lot that could be done.The money saved from funding this middle-class welfare state could be redeployed where it is needed. The priority would often be to invest in schools, so children get a fair start in life, and in adult education, so that older people whose skills become obsolete as a result of technology can retrain.Such a conception of fairness is not really new. It has a lot in common with classic liberalism. Nor is it dead. Successful politicians around the world — like Narendra Modi of India with his fight against corruption or Matteo Renzi of Italy with his willingness to confront some vested interests — are deploying some strategies from this playbook.It is a rich source of ideas with which to tackle the unfairness of capitalism without falling for the inefficiency of socialism.Hugo Dixon writes a biweekly column for Reuters Breakingviews. For more financial commentary, visit breakingviews.com.Advertisement

Headline: Donald Trump Might Not Keep Paying for His Campaign Himself, Chris Christie Suggests
News:
Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey told his finance team late Friday that he anticipates that Donald J. Trump, who often boasts that he is funding his own campaign, will begin to solicit campaign contributions as the race heads into a general election if Mr. Trump becomes the nominee.In a conference call hours after Mr. Christie endorsed Mr. Trump, his onetime rival, the governor was asked about what could be done to help Mr. Trump, who says he is a billionaire many times over.Mr. Christie replied that Mr. Trump, who has won three of the four first nominating contests, is currently self-funding.But, he added, “I sense that once we get to a general election campaign, that his posture may become different” given the scope and demands of a national campaign, and “how well-funded Hillary Clinton will be on the other side.”A Times reporter was allowed to listen in on the call by one of the participants.It was the first time there has been any indication that Mr. Trump might look to raise money in earnest. As of Jan. 31, he had lent his campaign $17 million, federal election reports showed. He has also raised several million dollars, primarily from smaller contributors. Most of his money has gone toward television ads.But Mr. Trump has said that he is mindful of his costs, and he has repeatedly talked about not wanting to spend money on a pollster or on advertising if he does not have to.A spokeswoman for Mr. Trump did not respond to an email seeking comment. Mr. Trump has used “self-funding” as a selling point to voters at his rallies. The claim is only partly true, as money he has raised from donors represents about a third of all the money his campaign has brought in over seven months. The rest is money he lent to his campaign.That has prompted a number of major donors, who backed other candidates and are now uncertain of what to do, wondering in private conversations about whether Mr. Trump will ultimately seek to secure their support down the road. But doing so would undercut Mr. Trump’s claim of independence from the party’s major figures, and potentially fuel lingering questions about how much money he has to spend personally. Yet the Trump campaign is said to be aware of potential pots of money that may be available eventually. According to people briefed on the exchanges, Trump campaign officials have appeared intrigued by how much money would be available to the nominee, and when, through the Republican National Committee should he become the nominee. A spokesman for the party committee did not immediately respond to an email. Meanwhile, on the finance network call, Mr. Christie also continued his slash-and-burn attacks on Senator Marco Rubio. When a person on the call asked how he would respond to Mr. Rubio’s concerns that Mr. Trump as the nominee would tear apart the Republican Party, Mr. Christie replied, “I would say to Marco that that’s what desperate people say in the last throes of a losing campaign.” He also pointed out that there was increased turnout in the Republican nominating contests in the first four states, and added that Mr. Rubio had also signed the loyalty pledge that all candidates put their names to last August vowing to support the eventual nominee.  Mr. Christie demurred when asked whether he would appear on a ticket with Mr. Trump, adding, “Donald and I haven’t had any conversations like that at all.” One donor on the call later was struck by the rawness of Mr. Christie’s anger at Mr. Rubio, whose supportive “super PAC” ran devastating ads that blunted Mr. Christie’s efforts at a political comeback in the New Hampshire primary.
